entry.title: Notes on Fermionic Systems
entry.content:
This is the note of my summer research after my junior yearï¼Œthe reference is the note of HH Tu,TENSOR NETWORKS (SS2021) Lecture 10&11ã€‚

Correlation matrix

For free fermionic system, providing TijT_{ij}Tijâ€‹ is symmetric, the generic Hamiltonian is:

H=âˆ‘j,l=1Ncjâ€ TjlclH = \sum_{j,l=1}^{N}c_j^{\dagger}T_{jl}c_l H=j,l=1âˆ‘Nâ€‹cjâ€ â€‹Tjlâ€‹clâ€‹

Diagonalizing TijT_{ij}Tijâ€‹ will give the operator dmâ€ ,dmd_m^\dagger,d_mdmâ€ â€‹,dmâ€‹,which is the creator/annihilator according to the energy of the mode:

H=âˆ‘j,l=1Ncjâ€ Tjlcl=âˆ‘m=1NÎµmdmâ€ dmH= \sum_{j,l=1}^{N}c_j^{\dagger}T_{jl}c_l =\sum_{m=1}^{N}\varepsilon_md_m^\dagger d_m H=j,l=1âˆ‘Nâ€‹cjâ€ â€‹Tjlâ€‹clâ€‹=m=1âˆ‘Nâ€‹Îµmâ€‹dmâ€ â€‹dmâ€‹

Selecting the negative energy mode which number is M gives the ground state:

âˆ£ÏˆâŸ©=âˆm=1Mdmâ€ âˆ£0âŸ©|\psi \rangle = \prod_{m=1}^{M}d_m^\dagger |0 \rangle âˆ£ÏˆâŸ©=m=1âˆMâ€‹dmâ€ â€‹âˆ£0âŸ©

Define the correlation matrix (correlation function in matrix form):

Glj=âŸ¨Ïˆâˆ£cjâ€ clâˆ£ÏˆâŸ©G_{lj} = \langle\psi|c_j^\dagger c_l|\psi\rangle Gljâ€‹=âŸ¨Ïˆâˆ£cjâ€ â€‹clâ€‹âˆ£ÏˆâŸ©

It has the property that the energy mode creators and annihilators diagonal the correlation matrix as follows:

\begin{align} \begin{aligned} (UGU^\dagger)_{m'm} &= \sum_{j,l=1}^{N}U_{m'l}\langle\psi|c_j^\dagger c_l|\psi\rangle U^\dagger _{jm}\\ &=\langle\psi|d_m^\dagger d_{m'}|\psi\rangle \end{aligned} \end{align}

For general pure state, the single-particle basis which diagonalizes ğº defines natural orbitals, which means even though the pure state is not the ground state, then there is possible that some modes(orbitals) may be not occupied.

Calculating the reduced density matrix

As mentioned above, for free fermions, the correlation matrix can be shown as:

\begin{align} G_{lj}^A &= \langle\psi|c_j^\dagger c_l|\psi\rangle\\ & = tr|\psi\rangle\langle\psi|c_j^\dagger c_l\\ & = tr_A{}tr_B \rho c_j^\dagger c_l \\ & = tr_A(\rho_Ac_j^\dagger c_l) \end{align}

If we diagonal the GAG^AGA , we have:

GljA=âˆ‘p=1NAVlpâ€ Î›pVpj,Î›pâˆˆ[0,1]Î›pÎ´ppâ€²=âˆ‘j,l=1NAVplGljAVjpâ€²â€ =âˆ‘j,l=1NAVpltrA(ÏAcjâ€ cl)Vjpâ€²â€ =trA(ÏAfpâ€²â€ fp)G^A_{lj}= \sum_{p=1}^{N_A}V_{lp}^\dagger \Lambda_pV_{pj},\Lambda_p \in [0,1]\\ \Lambda_p\delta_{pp'} = \sum_{j,l = 1}^{N_A}V_{pl}G^A_{lj}V^\dagger_{jp'}= \sum_{j,l = 1}^{N_A}V_{pl}tr_A(\rho_Ac_j^\dagger c_l)V^\dagger_{jp'} = tr_A(\rho_Af^\dagger_{p'}f_p) GljAâ€‹=p=1âˆ‘NAâ€‹â€‹Vlpâ€ â€‹Î›pâ€‹Vpjâ€‹,Î›pâ€‹âˆˆ[0,1]Î›pâ€‹Î´ppâ€²â€‹=j,l=1âˆ‘NAâ€‹â€‹Vplâ€‹GljAâ€‹Vjpâ€²â€ â€‹=j,l=1âˆ‘NAâ€‹â€‹Vplâ€‹trAâ€‹(ÏAâ€‹cjâ€ â€‹clâ€‹)Vjpâ€²â€ â€‹=trAâ€‹(ÏAâ€‹fpâ€²â€ â€‹fpâ€‹)

Meanwhile, if p=Ì¸pâ€²p\not= p'pî€ â€‹=pâ€², then trA(ÏAfpâ€²â€ fp)=0tr_A(\rho_Af^\dagger_{p'}f_p) = 0trAâ€‹(ÏAâ€‹fpâ€²â€ â€‹fpâ€‹)=0. What should be said is that here we defined a new set of creators and annihilators. From above, we have:

Î›p=trA(ÏAfpâ€ fp)1âˆ’Î›p=trA(ÏAfpfpâ€ )\Lambda_p = tr_A(\rho_Af^\dagger_{p}f_p)\\ 1-\Lambda_p = tr_A(\rho_Af_pf^\dagger_{p}) Î›pâ€‹=trAâ€‹(ÏAâ€‹fpâ€ â€‹fpâ€‹)1âˆ’Î›pâ€‹=trAâ€‹(ÏAâ€‹fpâ€‹fpâ€ â€‹)

From a clever perspective, we have:

ÏA=âˆp=1NA[Î›pfpâ€ fp+(1âˆ’Î›p)fpfpâ€ ]\rho_A = \prod_{p=1}^{N_A}[\Lambda_pf^\dagger_{p}f_p+(1-\Lambda_p )f_pf^\dagger_{p}] ÏAâ€‹=p=1âˆNAâ€‹â€‹[Î›pâ€‹fpâ€ â€‹fpâ€‹+(1âˆ’Î›pâ€‹)fpâ€‹fpâ€ â€‹]

This expression means that for free fermion system, the reduced density matrix can be writen as some direct products of two level system.

If we generate state vectors using fâ€ f^\daggerfâ€ , which meansâˆ£Î±âŸ©=âˆ£n1,n2,â€¦,nNAâŸ©|\alpha \rangle =|n_1,n_2,\ldots,n_{N_A}\rangleâˆ£Î±âŸ©=âˆ£n1â€‹,n2â€‹,â€¦,nNAâ€‹â€‹âŸ©, then:

ÏAâˆ£Î±âŸ©=âˆp=1NA[Î›pnp+(1âˆ’Î›p)(1âˆ’np)]âˆ£Î±âŸ©\rho_A|\alpha\rangle = \prod_{p=1}^{N_A}[\Lambda_pn_p+(1-\Lambda_p )(1-n_p)]|\alpha\rangle ÏAâ€‹âˆ£Î±âŸ©=p=1âˆNAâ€‹â€‹[Î›pâ€‹npâ€‹+(1âˆ’Î›pâ€‹)(1âˆ’npâ€‹)]âˆ£Î±âŸ©

In other words, âˆ£Î±âŸ©|\alpha \rangleâˆ£Î±âŸ© is the eigenvector of the reduced density matrix. Here, we define the entanglement spectrum as the eigenvalues of âˆ’lnâ¡ÏA-\ln\rho_Aâˆ’lnÏAâ€‹, and the entanglement Hamiltonian as ÏA=eâˆ’H\rho_A = e^{-H}ÏAâ€‹=eâˆ’H.

Because of the special property of anticommutation of fermion operator we can know that:

ÏAâˆexpâ¡[âˆ’âˆ‘p=1NAâˆ’lnâ¡(Î›p1âˆ’Î›p)fpâ€ fp]=expâ¡(âˆ’âˆ‘p=1NAÎµ~pfpâ€ fp)\rho_A \propto \exp[-\sum_{p=1}^{N_A}-\ln(\frac{\Lambda_p}{1-\Lambda_p})f_p^\dagger f_p]=\exp(-\sum_{p=1}^{N_A}\tilde\varepsilon_p f_p^\dagger f_p) ÏAâ€‹âˆexp[âˆ’p=1âˆ‘NAâ€‹â€‹âˆ’ln(1âˆ’Î›pâ€‹Î›pâ€‹â€‹)fpâ€ â€‹fpâ€‹]=exp(âˆ’p=1âˆ‘NAâ€‹â€‹Îµ~pâ€‹fpâ€ â€‹fpâ€‹)

which means zero mode indicates degeneracy in entanglement spectrum.

As equation (1) shown that free fermion state created by $f^\dagger $â€‹ is the eigenvector of the reduced density matrix, (NOTICE: the state is not necessarily to be the ground state) so The Schmidt decomposition can be computed exactly for free fermion systems.

If you want to calculate the entanglement entropy of the system, you can do it via what is said above. You can also compute the central charge of the system via entanglement entropy. (Maybe I should calculate one here.)

MPS for free fermion state

For MPS approximation, there is two way of doing truncation for free fermion systems. The first is Gaussian truncation, and the second is SVD truncation. The former keeps the nature of Gaussian state, in other words, stay to be the free fermion states. This can be seen in the paper: M. T. Fishman & S. R. White, Phys. Rev. B 92, 075132 (2015).

As equation (1) shown that free fermion state created by $f^\dagger $ is the eigenvector of the reduced density matrix, (NOTICE: the state is not necessarily to be the ground state) so The Schmidt decomposition can be computed exactly for free fermion systems.

So to write a free fermion state into MPS form require bipartitions steps, below is one example:

Any state $|\alpha \rangle $ can be written as a combination of $|\beta \rangle \bigotimes |n \rangle $:

âˆ£Î±âŸ©=âˆ‘Î²,nAÎ²Î±nâˆ£Î²âŸ©â¨‚âˆ£nâŸ©|\alpha \rangle =\sum_{\beta, n}A_{\beta\alpha}^{n} |\beta \rangle \bigotimes |n \rangle âˆ£Î±âŸ©=Î²,nâˆ‘â€‹AÎ²Î±nâ€‹âˆ£Î²âŸ©â¨‚âˆ£nâŸ©

what should be claimed here is that AÎ²Î±nA_{\beta\alpha}^nAÎ²Î±nâ€‹ is in a block diagonal form. Now we compute the coefficients using the results gained from correlation matrix and assuming n=0n=0n=0:

\begin{align} |\alpha \rangle &= f_1^\dagger \cdots f_m^\dagger |0 \rangle_{1\rightarrow i} =\prod_{p=1}^{m}\sum^i_{j=1}c_j^\dagger V_{jp}^\dagger |0 \rangle_{1\rightarrow i}=\prod_{p=1}^{m}\sum^i_{j=1}c_j^\dagger V_{jp}^\dagger |0 \rangle_{1\rightarrow i-1}\bigotimes |0 \rangle_i\\ |\beta \rangle &= \tilde f_1^\dagger \cdots \tilde f_m^\dagger |0 \rangle_{1\rightarrow i-1}=\prod_{p=1}^{m}\sum^{i-1}_{j=1}c_j^\dagger V{'}_{jp}^\dagger |0 \rangle_{1\rightarrow i-1}=\prod_{p=1}^{m}\sum^{i}_{j=1}c_j^\dagger \tilde V_{jp}^\dagger |0 \rangle_{1\rightarrow i-1} \end{align}

Remember in mind, V~â€ \tilde V^\daggerV~â€  is irreversible. As the set of âˆ£Î²âŸ©â¨‚âˆ£nâŸ©|\beta \rangle \bigotimes |n \rangleâˆ£Î²âŸ©â¨‚âˆ£nâŸ© forms the Schmidt vectors, we have:

AÎ²Î±0=(âŸ¨0âˆ£â¨‚âŸ¨Î²âˆ£)âˆ£Î±âŸ©=âŸ¨0âˆ£âˆp=m1âˆ‘j=1icjV~jpâˆpâ€²=1mâˆ‘jâ€²=1icjâ€²â€ Vjâ€²pâ€²â€ âˆ£0âŸ©A^0_{\beta\alpha} = (\langle 0|\bigotimes\langle\beta|)|\alpha \rangle = \langle 0|\prod_{p=m}^{1}\sum^{i}_{j=1}c_j \tilde V_{jp}\prod_{p'=1}^{m}\sum^i_{j'=1}c_{j'}^\dagger V_{j'p'}^\dagger |0\rangle AÎ²Î±0â€‹=(âŸ¨0âˆ£â¨‚âŸ¨Î²âˆ£)âˆ£Î±âŸ©=âŸ¨0âˆ£p=mâˆ1â€‹j=1âˆ‘iâ€‹cjâ€‹V~jpâ€‹pâ€²=1âˆmâ€‹jâ€²=1âˆ‘iâ€‹cjâ€²â€ â€‹Vjâ€²pâ€²â€ â€‹âˆ£0âŸ©

**(Personal statement)**Similarly, we can compute AÎ²Î±1A_{\beta\alpha}^{1}AÎ²Î±1â€‹, which requires different meaning of V~â€ \tilde V^\daggerV~â€ . Noticing the order of creators:

âˆ£Î²âŸ©â¨‚âˆ£1âŸ©=f~1â€ â‹¯f~mâˆ’1â€ ciâ€ âˆ£0âŸ©1â†’iâˆ’1â¨‚âˆ£0âŸ©i=âˆp=1mâˆ‘j=1icjâ€ V~jpâ€ âˆ£0âŸ©1â†’i|\beta \rangle \bigotimes |1 \rangle = \tilde f_1^\dagger \cdots \tilde f_{m-1}^\dagger c_i^\dagger|0 \rangle_{1\rightarrow i-1}\bigotimes |0 \rangle_i =\prod_{p=1}^{m}\sum^i_{j=1}c_j^\dagger \tilde V_{jp}^\dagger |0 \rangle_{1\rightarrow i} âˆ£Î²âŸ©â¨‚âˆ£1âŸ©=f~â€‹1â€ â€‹â‹¯f~â€‹mâˆ’1â€ â€‹ciâ€ â€‹âˆ£0âŸ©1â†’iâˆ’1â€‹â¨‚âˆ£0âŸ©iâ€‹=p=1âˆmâ€‹j=1âˆ‘iâ€‹cjâ€ â€‹V~jpâ€ â€‹âˆ£0âŸ©1â†’iâ€‹

The following procedure ends up with the same answer. In this way we can write down the MPS form of free fermion state.

Convert a Fermion sea into MPS state

According to the creators and annihilators for different eigenstates of energy modes, these operators is just a combination of that according to sites:

\begin{align} d_m^\dagger &= \sum_{l=1}^{N}A_{ml}c^\dagger_l\\ & = \begin{pmatrix} 0 &1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 &0\\ A_{m1}c_1^\dagger &1\\ \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 &0\\ A_{m2}c_2^\dagger &1\\ \end{pmatrix} \cdots \begin{pmatrix} 1 &0\\ A_{mN}c_N^\dagger &1\\ \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ \end{pmatrix} \end{align}

What should be noticed is that matrix AAA and matrix UUU is not the same, i.e. A=(Uâ€ )T=Uâˆ—A = (U^\dagger)^T = U^*A=(Uâ€ )T=Uâˆ— . Here we use use Jordan-Wigner transformation to introduce a correspondence between fermion creators and spin operators:

clâ€ =(âˆ’Ïƒ1z)â‹¯(âˆ’Ïƒlâˆ’1z)Ïƒl+c_l^\dagger = (-\sigma_1^z)\cdots(-\sigma_{l-1}^z)\sigma_l^+ clâ€ â€‹=(âˆ’Ïƒ1zâ€‹)â‹¯(âˆ’Ïƒlâˆ’1zâ€‹)Ïƒl+â€‹

In that case, we have:

dmâ€ =(01)(10Am1Ïƒ1+âˆ’Ïƒ1z)(10Am2Ïƒ2+âˆ’Ïƒ2z)â‹¯(10AmNÏƒN+âˆ’ÏƒNz)(10)d_m^\dagger = \begin{pmatrix} 0 &1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 &0\\ A_{m1}\sigma_1^+ &-\sigma_1^z\\ \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 &0\\ A_{m2}\sigma_2^+ &-\sigma_2^z\\ \end{pmatrix} \cdots \begin{pmatrix} 1 &0\\ A_{mN}\sigma_N^+ &-\sigma_N^z\\ \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ \end{pmatrix} dmâ€ â€‹=(0â€‹1â€‹)(1Am1â€‹Ïƒ1+â€‹â€‹0âˆ’Ïƒ1zâ€‹â€‹)(1Am2â€‹Ïƒ2+â€‹â€‹0âˆ’Ïƒ2zâ€‹â€‹)â‹¯(1AmNâ€‹ÏƒN+â€‹â€‹0âˆ’ÏƒNzâ€‹â€‹)(10â€‹)

So here we have successfully written the creator as a MPO. Graphically, that is as follows.

The different quantities for different indexes is as follows:

In a nutshell, the Fermi sea can be written in a sequence of MPO. As a consequence, the bond dimension will increase exponentially. So at some point truncation is needed. High fidelity compression requires low-entanglement â€œintermediateâ€ states (This statement can be seen as the result of Jensen Inequality).

Truncation procedure for MPO-MPS evolution

SVD truncation for a given MPS

The truncation is a process described as follows graphically :

To understand what Iâ€™m doing here, you may consult the previous article.

From Matrix Product State(MPS) to DMRGï¼ˆ1ï¼‰

What should be stressed here is the process of QR decomposition: as we want to use SVD decomposition to maximize the approximation, we should put the MPS state in the canonical form, i.e. the state should consisted of Schmidt vectors for different blocks.

If you are not satisfied with the accuracy of SVD truncation, you may use DMRG to â€œsweepâ€ to get a better result.

Different type of oporators

As we mentioned above, in the process of applying the MPOs, we need low-entanglement â€œintermediateâ€ states. For dmâ€ d_m^\daggerdmâ€ â€‹, it usually create the non-local particle mode. You can easily check the 1D chain of tight binding model to verify the statement.

Here we want to deduce more local creators using the negative energy mode, which canâ€™t be the the initial ciâ€ c_i^\daggerciâ€ â€‹ for there exist positive energy mode. We use the position operator X=âˆ‘llclâ€ clX = \sum_llc_l^\dagger c_lX=âˆ‘lâ€‹lclâ€ â€‹clâ€‹, i.e. XXX can give the expectation value of stateâ€™s position.

Construct the matrix X~nm=âŸ¨0âˆ£dmâ€ dmâ€²âˆ£0âŸ©\tilde X_{nm} = \langle 0|d_m^\dagger d_{m'}|0\rangleX~nmâ€‹=âŸ¨0âˆ£dmâ€ â€‹dmâ€²â€‹âˆ£0âŸ© and diagonal the matrix, we get a spectrum of position operator and a unitary matrix UUU. Then we can construct frâ€ f_r^\daggerfrâ€ â€‹:

UX~Uâ€ =diag(x1,â€¦,xM)frâ€ =âˆ‘l=1MUrldlâ€ =âˆ‘l=1N(UA)rlclâ€ U\tilde X U^\dagger = diag(x_1,\ldots,x_M)\\ f_r^\dagger = \sum_{l=1}^MU_{rl}d^\dagger_l = \sum_{l=1}^N(UA)_{rl}c^\dagger_l UX~Uâ€ =diag(x1â€‹,â€¦,xMâ€‹)frâ€ â€‹=l=1âˆ‘Mâ€‹Urlâ€‹dlâ€ â€‹=l=1âˆ‘Nâ€‹(UA)rlâ€‹clâ€ â€‹

Q: Why this represent Wannier orbitals?

From what is shown in the Proof picture, we know that we can use the new operators to get a state created by the old ones up to a trivial phase factor. As a trick to suppress entanglement growth, we may use â€œleft meet rightâ€ way instead of creating from left to right.

Time evolution in MPO-MPS form

When we discuss evolution of states, we may translate that process into MPS-MPS form. Especially for imaginary-time evolution, which is heading towards th ground state of the system.

For lattice model, we may separate different part of Hamiltonian and manipulate the MPO in a sequence. For the separated parts commute with each other, we just do two steps of MPO. Notice: Here SVD(QR) decomposition is some what used.

For non-commuting case, we just divide the time evolution into small steps, just as what we do in deducing the path integral formula. This will require a long sequence of MPO.

entry.title: Note on Lieb-Robinson Bound(1)
entry.content:
This note mainly focus on the basis of Lieb-Robinson Bound, considering the application towards correlation function, topological order, and nonrelativistic Goldstone theorem. The main references are:

[1] An Online Chinese Note

[2] M. B. Hastings, Locality in Quantum Systems.

Part. 1 Lieb-Robinson Bound

Consider H=âˆ‘ZHZH=\sum_ZH_ZH=âˆ‘Zâ€‹HZâ€‹, where ZZZ is denoted as a set of lattice site and âˆ¥HZâˆ¥\| H_Z\|âˆ¥HZâ€‹âˆ¥ decays exponentially.

Theorem 1

Suppose for site i, we have:

âˆ‘Xâˆ‹iâˆ¥HXâˆ¥âˆ£Xâˆ£expâ¡[Î¼diam(X)]â‰¤s<âˆ,Â Â Â Î¼,s>0\sum_{X\ni i}\|H_X\||X|\exp[\mu {\rm diam}(X)]\leq s< \infty, ~~~\mu,s>0 Xâˆ‹iâˆ‘â€‹âˆ¥HXâ€‹âˆ¥âˆ£Xâˆ£exp[Î¼diam(X)]â‰¤s<âˆ,Â Â Â Î¼,s>0

Let A,BA,BA,B to be bosonic operators supported on sets X,YX,YX,Y(dist(X,Y)>0{\rm dist}(X,Y)>0dist(X,Y)>0), then:

âˆ¥[A(t),B]âˆ¥â‰¤2âˆ¥Aâˆ¥âˆ¥Bâˆ¥âˆ‘iâˆˆXexpâ¡[âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y)](e2sâˆ£tâˆ£âˆ’1)â‰¤2âˆ¥Aâˆ¥âˆ¥Bâˆ¥âˆ£Xâˆ£expâ¡[âˆ’Î¼dist(X,Y)](e2sâˆ£tâˆ£âˆ’1)\begin{aligned} \|[A(t),B]\|&\leq 2\|A\|\|B\|\sum_{i\in X}\exp[-\mu{\rm dist}(i,Y)](e^{2s|t|}-1)\\ &\leq 2\|A\|\|B\||X|\exp[-\mu{\rm dist}(X,Y)](e^{2s|t|}-1)\\ \end{aligned} âˆ¥[A(t),B]âˆ¥â€‹â‰¤2âˆ¥Aâˆ¥âˆ¥Bâˆ¥iâˆˆXâˆ‘â€‹exp[âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y)](e2sâˆ£tâˆ£âˆ’1)â‰¤2âˆ¥Aâˆ¥âˆ¥Bâˆ¥âˆ£Xâˆ£exp[âˆ’Î¼dist(X,Y)](e2sâˆ£tâˆ£âˆ’1)â€‹

Proof:

Let tn=tNn=nÏµt_n=\frac{t}{N}n=n\epsilontnâ€‹=Ntâ€‹n=nÏµ, with N is large, and IX=âˆ‘Z:Zâˆ©Xâ‰ âˆ…HZI_X = \sum_{Z:Z \cap X \neq\varnothing}H_ZIXâ€‹=âˆ‘Z:Zâˆ©Xî€ â€‹=âˆ…â€‹HZâ€‹.

âˆ¥[A(t),B]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A(0),B]âˆ¥=âˆ‘n=0Nâˆ’1Ïµâˆ¥[A(t<!âˆ’âˆ’swigï¿¼0âˆ’âˆ’>),B]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A(tn),B]âˆ¥Ïµ\|[A(t),B]\|-\|[A(0),B]\|= \sum_{n=0}^{N-1}\epsilon\frac{\|[A(t_NaN),B]\|-\|[A(t_n),B]\|}{\epsilon} âˆ¥[A(t),B]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A(0),B]âˆ¥=n=0âˆ‘Nâˆ’1â€‹ÏµÏµâˆ¥[A(t<â€‹!âˆ’âˆ’swigï¿¼0âˆ’âˆ’>),B]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A(tnâ€‹),B]âˆ¥â€‹

âˆ¥[A(t<!âˆ’âˆ’swigï¿¼1âˆ’âˆ’>),B]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A(tn),B]âˆ¥=âˆ¥[A(Ïµ),B(âˆ’tn)]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A,B(âˆ’tn)]âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥[A+iÏµ[H,A],B(âˆ’tn)]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A,B(âˆ’tn)]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ2)=âˆ¥[A+iÏµ[IX,A],B(âˆ’tn)]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A,B(âˆ’tn)]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ2)\begin{aligned} \|[A(t_NaN),B]\|-\|[A(t_n),B]\| &= \|[A(\epsilon),B(-t_n)]\|-\|[A,B(-t_n)]\|\\ &\leq\|[A+i\epsilon[H,A],B(-t_n)]\|-\|[A,B(-t_n)]\|+\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^2)\\ &=\|[A+i\epsilon[I_X,A],B(-t_n)]\|-\|[A,B(-t_n)]\|+\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^2)\\ \end{aligned} âˆ¥[A(t<â€‹!âˆ’âˆ’swigï¿¼1âˆ’âˆ’>),B]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A(tnâ€‹),B]âˆ¥â€‹=âˆ¥[A(Ïµ),B(âˆ’tnâ€‹)]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A,B(âˆ’tnâ€‹)]âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥[A+iÏµ[H,A],B(âˆ’tnâ€‹)]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A,B(âˆ’tnâ€‹)]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ2)=âˆ¥[A+iÏµ[IXâ€‹,A],B(âˆ’tnâ€‹)]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A,B(âˆ’tnâ€‹)]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ2)â€‹

âˆ¥[A+iÏµ[IX,A],B(âˆ’tn)]âˆ¥=âˆ¥[eiÏµIXAeâˆ’iÏµIX,B(âˆ’tn)]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ2)=âˆ¥[A,eâˆ’iÏµIXB(âˆ’tn)eiÏµIX]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ2)â‰¤âˆ¥[A,B(âˆ’tn)]âˆ¥+Ïµâˆ¥[A,[IX,B(âˆ’tn)]]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ2)\begin{aligned} \|[A+i\epsilon[I_X,A],B(-t_n)]\|&=\|[e^{i\epsilon I_X}Ae^{-i\epsilon I_X},B(-t_n)]\|+\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^2)\\ &=\|[A,e^{-i\epsilon I_X}B(-t_n)e^{i\epsilon I_X}]\|+\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^2)\\ &\leq\|[A,B(-t_n)]\|+\epsilon\|[A,[I_X,B(-t_n)]]\|+\mathcal{O}(\epsilon^2)\\ \end{aligned} âˆ¥[A+iÏµ[IXâ€‹,A],B(âˆ’tnâ€‹)]âˆ¥â€‹=âˆ¥[eiÏµIXâ€‹Aeâˆ’iÏµIXâ€‹,B(âˆ’tnâ€‹)]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ2)=âˆ¥[A,eâˆ’iÏµIXâ€‹B(âˆ’tnâ€‹)eiÏµIXâ€‹]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ2)â‰¤âˆ¥[A,B(âˆ’tnâ€‹)]âˆ¥+Ïµâˆ¥[A,[IXâ€‹,B(âˆ’tnâ€‹)]]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ2)â€‹

Then we obtain:

âˆ¥[A(t),B]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A(0),B]âˆ¥=2âˆ¥Aâˆ¥âˆ‘n=0Nâˆ’1Ïµâˆ‘Z:Zâˆ©Xâ‰ âˆ…âˆ¥[HZ,B(âˆ’tn)]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ)=2âˆ¥Aâˆ¥âˆ‘n=0Nâˆ’1âˆ‘Z:Zâˆ©Xâ‰ âˆ…Ïµâˆ¥[HZ(tn),B]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ)=2âˆ¥Aâˆ¥âˆ‘Z:Zâˆ©Xâ‰ âˆ…âˆ«0âˆ£tâˆ£dxâˆ¥[HZ(x),B]âˆ¥\begin{aligned} \|[A(t),B]\|-\|[A(0),B]\|&=2\|A\| \sum_{n=0}^{N-1}\epsilon\sum_{Z:Z \cap X \neq\varnothing}\|[H_Z,B(-t_n)]\|+\mathcal{O}(\epsilon)\\ &=2\|A\| \sum_{n=0}^{N-1}\sum_{Z:Z \cap X \neq\varnothing}\epsilon\|[H_Z(t_n),B]\|+\mathcal{O}(\epsilon)\\ &=2\|A\|\sum_{Z:Z \cap X \neq\varnothing}\int_0^{|t|}dx\|[H_Z(x),B]\|\\ \end{aligned} âˆ¥[A(t),B]âˆ¥âˆ’âˆ¥[A(0),B]âˆ¥â€‹=2âˆ¥Aâˆ¥n=0âˆ‘Nâˆ’1â€‹ÏµZ:Zâˆ©Xî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ¥[HZâ€‹,B(âˆ’tnâ€‹)]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ)=2âˆ¥Aâˆ¥n=0âˆ‘Nâˆ’1â€‹Z:Zâˆ©Xî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹Ïµâˆ¥[HZâ€‹(tnâ€‹),B]âˆ¥+O(Ïµ)=2âˆ¥Aâˆ¥Z:Zâˆ©Xî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ«0âˆ£tâˆ£â€‹dxâˆ¥[HZâ€‹(x),B]âˆ¥â€‹

Approximation: using the upper limit to control the bound.

Define CB(X,t):=supâ¡AâˆˆAXâˆ¥[A(t),B]âˆ¥âˆ¥Aâˆ¥C_B(X,t):=\sup_{A\in\mathcal{A}_X}\frac{\|[A(t),B]\|}{\|A\|}CBâ€‹(X,t):=supAâˆˆAXâ€‹â€‹âˆ¥Aâˆ¥âˆ¥[A(t),B]âˆ¥â€‹, then we have CB(X,0)=0C_B(X,0)=0CBâ€‹(X,0)=0 fordist(X,Y)>0{\rm dist}(X,Y)>0dist(X,Y)>0 and :CB(Z,0)â‰¤2âˆ¥Bâˆ¥C_B(Z,0)\leq2\|B\|CBâ€‹(Z,0)â‰¤2âˆ¥Bâˆ¥

CB(X,t)â‰¤2âˆ¥HZâˆ¥âˆ‘Z:Zâˆ©Xâ‰ âˆ…âˆ«0âˆ£tâˆ£dxCB(Z,x)â‰¤2âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥âˆ‘Z1:Z1âˆ©Xâ‰ âˆ…âˆ«0âˆ£tâˆ£dxCB(Z,0)+22âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2âˆ¥âˆ‘Z1:Z1âˆ©Xâ‰ âˆ…âˆ‘Z2:Z2âˆ©Z1â‰ âˆ…âˆ«0âˆ£tâˆ£âˆ«0âˆ£xâˆ£dxdyCB(Z,y)â‰¤2(2âˆ£tâˆ£)âˆ¥Bâˆ¥âˆ‘Z1:Z1âˆ©Xâ‰ âˆ…,Z1âˆ©Yâ‰ âˆ…âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥+2(2âˆ£tâˆ£)22!âˆ¥Bâˆ¥âˆ‘Z1:Z1âˆ©Xâ‰ âˆ…âˆ‘Z2:Z2âˆ©Z1â‰ âˆ…,Z2âˆ©Yâ‰ âˆ…âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2âˆ¥+â‹¯\begin{aligned} C_B(X,t)&\leq2\|H_Z\|\sum_{Z:Z \cap X \neq\varnothing}\int_0^{|t|}dxC_B(Z,x)\\ &\leq2\|H_{Z_1}\|\sum_{Z_1:Z_1 \cap X \neq\varnothing}\int_0^{|t|}dxC_B(Z,0)\\ &+2^2\|H_{Z_1}\|\|H_{Z_2}\|\sum_{Z_1:Z_1 \cap X \neq\varnothing}\sum_{Z_2:Z_2 \cap Z_1 \neq\varnothing}\int_0^{|t|}\int_0^{|x|}dxdyC_B(Z,y)\\ &\leq2(2|t|)\|B\|\sum_{Z_1:Z_1 \cap X \neq\varnothing,Z_1\cap Y\neq\varnothing}\|H_{Z_1}\|+2\frac{(2|t|)^2}{2!}\|B\|\sum_{Z_1:Z_1 \cap X \neq\varnothing}\sum_{Z_2:Z_2 \cap Z_1 \neq\varnothing,Z_2\cap Y\neq\varnothing}\|H_{Z_1}\|\|H_{Z_2}\|+\cdots \end{aligned} CBâ€‹(X,t)â€‹â‰¤2âˆ¥HZâ€‹âˆ¥Z:Zâˆ©Xî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ«0âˆ£tâˆ£â€‹dxCBâ€‹(Z,x)â‰¤2âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥Z1â€‹:Z1â€‹âˆ©Xî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ«0âˆ£tâˆ£â€‹dxCBâ€‹(Z,0)+22âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2â€‹â€‹âˆ¥Z1â€‹:Z1â€‹âˆ©Xî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹Z2â€‹:Z2â€‹âˆ©Z1â€‹î€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ«0âˆ£tâˆ£â€‹âˆ«0âˆ£xâˆ£â€‹dxdyCBâ€‹(Z,y)â‰¤2(2âˆ£tâˆ£)âˆ¥Bâˆ¥Z1â€‹:Z1â€‹âˆ©Xî€ â€‹=âˆ…,Z1â€‹âˆ©Yî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥+22!(2âˆ£tâˆ£)2â€‹âˆ¥Bâˆ¥Z1â€‹:Z1â€‹âˆ©Xî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹Z2â€‹:Z2â€‹âˆ©Z1â€‹î€ â€‹=âˆ…,Z2â€‹âˆ©Yî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2â€‹â€‹âˆ¥+â‹¯â€‹

For the first term, we have:

âˆ‘Z1:Z1âˆ©Xâ‰ âˆ…,Z1âˆ©Yâ‰ âˆ…âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ‘iâˆˆXâˆ‘Z1âˆ‹i,Z1âˆ©Yâ‰ âˆ…âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥\sum_{Z_1:Z_1 \cap X \neq\varnothing,Z_1\cap Y\neq\varnothing}\|H_{Z_1}\|\leq\sum_{i\in X}\sum_{Z_1\ni i,Z_1\cap Y\neq\varnothing}\|H_{Z_1}\| Z1â€‹:Z1â€‹âˆ©Xî€ â€‹=âˆ…,Z1â€‹âˆ©Yî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥â‰¤iâˆˆXâˆ‘â€‹Z1â€‹âˆ‹i,Z1â€‹âˆ©Yî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥

In case that Z1âˆ©Yâ‰ âˆ…Z_1\cap Y\neq\varnothingZ1â€‹âˆ©Yî€ â€‹=âˆ…, then dist(i,Y)â‰¤diam(Z){\rm dist}(i,Y)\leq {\rm diam}(Z)dist(i,Y)â‰¤diam(Z), which means:

âˆ‘Z1:Z1âˆ©Xâ‰ âˆ…,Z1âˆ©Yâ‰ âˆ…âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ‘iâˆˆXexpâ¡(âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y))\sum_{Z_1:Z_1 \cap X \neq\varnothing,Z_1\cap Y\neq\varnothing}\|H_{Z_1}\|\leq \sum_{i\in X}\exp(-\mu{\rm dist}(i,Y)) Z1â€‹:Z1â€‹âˆ©Xî€ â€‹=âˆ…,Z1â€‹âˆ©Yî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥â‰¤iâˆˆXâˆ‘â€‹exp(âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y))

For the second term, we have:

âˆ‘Z1:Z1âˆ©Xâ‰ âˆ…âˆ‘Z2:Z2âˆ©Z1â‰ âˆ…,Z2âˆ©Yâ‰ âˆ…âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2âˆ¥=âˆ‘iâˆˆXâˆ‘Z1âˆ‹iâˆ‘jâˆˆZ1âˆ‘Z2âˆ‹j,Z2âˆ©Yâ‰ âˆ…âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ‘iâˆˆXâˆ‘Z1âˆ‹iâˆ‘jâˆˆZ1âˆ‘Z2âˆ‹j,Z2âˆ©Yâ‰ âˆ…âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2âˆ¥expâ¡(âˆ’dist(i,Y))expâ¡(dist(i,j))expâ¡(dist(j,Y))=âˆ‘iâˆˆXâˆ‘Z1âˆ‹iâˆ‘jâˆˆZ1expâ¡(âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y))expâ¡(Î¼dist(i,j))âˆ‘Z2âˆ‹j,Z2âˆ©Yâ‰ âˆ…âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2âˆ¥expâ¡(Î¼dist(j,Y))â‰¤âˆ‘iâˆˆXâˆ‘Z1âˆ‹iâˆ‘jâˆˆZ1expâ¡(âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y))expâ¡(Î¼dist(i,j))âˆ‘Z2âˆ‹j,Z2âˆ©Yâ‰ âˆ…âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2âˆ¥expâ¡(Î¼diam(Z2))â‰¤âˆ‘iâˆˆXâˆ‘Z1âˆ‹iâˆ‘jâˆˆZ1expâ¡(âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y))expâ¡(Î¼dist(i,j))âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥sâ‰¤âˆ‘iâˆˆXâˆ‘Z1âˆ‹iexpâ¡(âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y))expâ¡(Î¼diam(Z1))âˆ¥HZ1âˆ¥sâˆ£Z1âˆ£â‰¤âˆ‘iâˆˆXexpâ¡(âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y))s2\begin{aligned} &\sum_{Z_1:Z_1 \cap X \neq\varnothing}\sum_{Z_2:Z_2 \cap Z_1 \neq\varnothing,Z_2\cap Y\neq\varnothing}\|H_{Z_1}\|\|H_{Z_2}\|\\ &=\sum_{i\in X}\sum_{Z_1 \ni i}\sum_{j\in Z_1}\sum_{Z_2\ni j,Z_2\cap Y\neq \varnothing}\|H_{Z_1}\|\|H_{Z_2}\|\\ &\leq\sum_{i\in X}\sum_{Z_1 \ni i}\sum_{j\in Z_1}\sum_{Z_2\ni j,Z_2\cap Y\neq \varnothing}\|H_{Z_1}\|\|H_{Z_2}\|\exp(-{\rm dist}(i,Y))\exp({\rm dist}(i,j))\exp({\rm dist}(j,Y))\\ &= \sum_{i\in X}\sum_{Z_1 \ni i}\sum_{j\in Z_1}\exp(-{\mu\rm dist}(i,Y))\exp(\mu{\rm dist}(i,j))\sum_{Z_2\ni j,Z_2\cap Y\neq \varnothing}\|H_{Z_1}\|\|H_{Z_2}\|\exp(\mu{\rm dist}(j,Y))\\ &\leq \sum_{i\in X}\sum_{Z_1 \ni i}\sum_{j\in Z_1}\exp(-\mu{\rm dist}(i,Y))\exp(\mu{\rm dist}(i,j))\sum_{Z_2\ni j,Z_2\cap Y\neq \varnothing}\|H_{Z_1}\|\|H_{Z_2}\|\exp(\mu{\rm diam}(Z_2))\\ &\leq \sum_{i\in X}\sum_{Z_1 \ni i}\sum_{j\in Z_1}\exp(-\mu{\rm dist}(i,Y))\exp(\mu{\rm dist}(i,j))\|H_{Z_1}\|s\\ &\leq \sum_{i\in X}\sum_{Z_1 \ni i}\exp(-\mu{\rm dist}(i,Y))\exp(\mu{\rm diam}(Z_1))\|H_{Z_1}\|s|Z_1|\\ &\leq \sum_{i\in X}\exp(-\mu{\rm dist}(i,Y))s^2\\ \end{aligned} â€‹Z1â€‹:Z1â€‹âˆ©Xî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹Z2â€‹:Z2â€‹âˆ©Z1â€‹î€ â€‹=âˆ…,Z2â€‹âˆ©Yî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2â€‹â€‹âˆ¥=iâˆˆXâˆ‘â€‹Z1â€‹âˆ‹iâˆ‘â€‹jâˆˆZ1â€‹âˆ‘â€‹Z2â€‹âˆ‹j,Z2â€‹âˆ©Yî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2â€‹â€‹âˆ¥â‰¤iâˆˆXâˆ‘â€‹Z1â€‹âˆ‹iâˆ‘â€‹jâˆˆZ1â€‹âˆ‘â€‹Z2â€‹âˆ‹j,Z2â€‹âˆ©Yî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2â€‹â€‹âˆ¥exp(âˆ’dist(i,Y))exp(dist(i,j))exp(dist(j,Y))=iâˆˆXâˆ‘â€‹Z1â€‹âˆ‹iâˆ‘â€‹jâˆˆZ1â€‹âˆ‘â€‹exp(âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y))exp(Î¼dist(i,j))Z2â€‹âˆ‹j,Z2â€‹âˆ©Yî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2â€‹â€‹âˆ¥exp(Î¼dist(j,Y))â‰¤iâˆˆXâˆ‘â€‹Z1â€‹âˆ‹iâˆ‘â€‹jâˆˆZ1â€‹âˆ‘â€‹exp(âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y))exp(Î¼dist(i,j))Z2â€‹âˆ‹j,Z2â€‹âˆ©Yî€ â€‹=âˆ…âˆ‘â€‹âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥âˆ¥HZ2â€‹â€‹âˆ¥exp(Î¼diam(Z2â€‹))â‰¤iâˆˆXâˆ‘â€‹Z1â€‹âˆ‹iâˆ‘â€‹jâˆˆZ1â€‹âˆ‘â€‹exp(âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y))exp(Î¼dist(i,j))âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥sâ‰¤iâˆˆXâˆ‘â€‹Z1â€‹âˆ‹iâˆ‘â€‹exp(âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y))exp(Î¼diam(Z1â€‹))âˆ¥HZ1â€‹â€‹âˆ¥sâˆ£Z1â€‹âˆ£â‰¤iâˆˆXâˆ‘â€‹exp(âˆ’Î¼dist(i,Y))s2â€‹

Higher order terms follows the same procedure. Then,

CB(X,t)â‰¤2âˆ¥Bâˆ¥âˆ‘iâˆˆXexpâ¡[âˆ’Î¼dist(X,Y)](e2sâˆ£tâˆ£âˆ’1)C_B(X,t)\leq2\|B\|\sum_{i \in X}\exp[-\mu{\rm dist}(X,Y)](e^{2s|t|}-1) CBâ€‹(X,t)â‰¤2âˆ¥Bâˆ¥iâˆˆXâˆ‘â€‹exp[âˆ’Î¼dist(X,Y)](e2sâˆ£tâˆ£âˆ’1)

Q.E.D.

We now have Lieb-Robinson bound with the form:

âˆ¥[A(t),B]âˆ¥â‰¤2âˆ¥Aâˆ¥âˆ¥Bâˆ¥âˆ£Xâˆ£expâ¡[âˆ’Î¼dist(X,Y)](e2sâˆ£tâˆ£âˆ’1)\|[A(t),B]\|\leq 2\|A\|\|B\||X|\exp[-\mu{\rm dist}(X,Y)](e^{2s|t|}-1)\\ âˆ¥[A(t),B]âˆ¥â‰¤2âˆ¥Aâˆ¥âˆ¥Bâˆ¥âˆ£Xâˆ£exp[âˆ’Î¼dist(X,Y)](e2sâˆ£tâˆ£âˆ’1)

We can then deduce another form setting a constant vLRv_{LR}vLRâ€‹ such that for tâ‰¤dist(X,Y)/vLRt\leq {\rm dist}(X,Y)/v_{LR}tâ‰¤dist(X,Y)/vLRâ€‹,

âˆ¥[A(t),B]âˆ¥â‰¤vLRtlâˆ¥Aâˆ¥âˆ¥Bâˆ¥âˆ£Xâˆ£g(l),l=dist(X,Y)\|[A(t),B]\|\leq \frac{v_{LR}t}{l}\|A\|\|B\||X|g(l),l={\rm dist}(X,Y) âˆ¥[A(t),B]âˆ¥â‰¤lvLRâ€‹tâ€‹âˆ¥Aâˆ¥âˆ¥Bâˆ¥âˆ£Xâˆ£g(l),l=dist(X,Y)

Apparently, vLR=4s/Î¼v_{LR}=4s/\muvLRâ€‹=4s/Î¼ is a plausible choice.

entry.title: Notes on strong correlated system(1)
entry.content:
This is a note for the reading of the 2nd yellow book by Nagaosa.

Bosonization

The example we will discuss is one of the so-called Tomonaga-Luttinger liquids, XXZ model.

For XXZ model, the Halmiltonian is:

H=JâŠ¥âˆ‘i(SixSi+1x+SiySi+1y)+Jzâˆ‘iSizSi+1z=JâŠ¥2âˆ‘i(Si+Si+1âˆ’+Siâˆ’Si+1+)+Jzâˆ‘iSizSi+1zH = J_\perp\sum_i(S^x_iS^x_{i+1}+S^y_iS^y_{i+1})+J_z\sum_iS_i^zS_{i+1}^z=\frac{J_\perp}{2}\sum_i(S^+_iS^-_{i+1}+S^-_iS^+_{i+1})+J_z\sum_iS_i^zS_{i+1}^z H=JâŠ¥â€‹iâˆ‘â€‹(Sixâ€‹Si+1xâ€‹+Siyâ€‹Si+1yâ€‹)+Jzâ€‹iâˆ‘â€‹Sizâ€‹Si+1zâ€‹=2JâŠ¥â€‹â€‹iâˆ‘â€‹(Si+â€‹Si+1âˆ’â€‹+Siâˆ’â€‹Si+1+â€‹)+Jzâ€‹iâˆ‘â€‹Sizâ€‹Si+1zâ€‹

For the discrete case, we have the Hamiltonian (Using the technique of Jordan-Wigner Transformation):

H=âˆ’JâŠ¥2âˆ‘i=1N(fiâ€ fi+1+fi+1â€ fi)+Jzâˆ‘i=1N(fiâ€ fiâˆ’12)(fi+1â€ fi+1âˆ’12)=H1+H2H = -\frac{J_\perp}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{N}(f_i^\dagger f_{i+1}+f_{i+1}^\dagger f_i)+J_z\sum_{i=1}^{N}(f_i^\dagger f_i-\frac{1}{2})(f_{i+1}^\dagger f_{i+1}-\frac{1}{2}) = H_1+H_2 H=âˆ’2JâŠ¥â€‹â€‹i=1âˆ‘Nâ€‹(fiâ€ â€‹fi+1â€‹+fi+1â€ â€‹fiâ€‹)+Jzâ€‹i=1âˆ‘Nâ€‹(fiâ€ â€‹fiâ€‹âˆ’21â€‹)(fi+1â€ â€‹fi+1â€‹âˆ’21â€‹)=H1â€‹+H2â€‹

If we introduce the Fourier transformation:

fn=1Nâˆ‘kfkeikn,fnâ€ =1Nâˆ‘kfkâ€ eâˆ’iknf_n = \frac{1}{\sqrt{N} }\sum_kf_ke^{ikn},f_n^\dagger = \frac{1}{\sqrt{N} }\sum_kf_k^\dagger e^{-ikn} fnâ€‹=Nâ€‹1â€‹kâˆ‘â€‹fkâ€‹eikn,fnâ€ â€‹=Nâ€‹1â€‹kâˆ‘â€‹fkâ€ â€‹eâˆ’ikn

Then we have:

H1=âˆ‘k(âˆ’JâŠ¥cosâ¡k)fkâ€ fkH_1 = \sum_k (-J_\perp \cos k)f_k^\dagger f_k H1â€‹=kâˆ‘â€‹(âˆ’JâŠ¥â€‹cosk)fkâ€ â€‹fkâ€‹

We treat JzJ_zJzâ€‹ as perturbation, and in case that Stotz=0S_{tot}^z = 0Stotzâ€‹=0, we have the the ground state of H1H_1H1â€‹ is just the Fermi sea state (just from the fact that Siz=fiâ€ fiâˆ’12S_i^z = f_i^\dagger f_i-\frac{1}{2}Sizâ€‹=fiâ€ â€‹fiâ€‹âˆ’21â€‹). We can see immediately that H2H_2H2â€‹ is the particle-hole excitation as we look back at the original Hamiltonian that H2H_2H2â€‹ will not change the z-spin of each site.

From the perspective of perturbation, the low-energy particle-hole exitation near the Fermi surface will be dominant.

1st step: Linearization

In case that only the vicinity of the Fermi surface that counts, we replace the dispersion relation Îµk=âˆ’JâŠ¥cosâ¡k\varepsilon_k = -J_\perp \cos kÎµkâ€‹=âˆ’JâŠ¥â€‹cosk by two linearized dispersion relationship, and also only consider the creation/annihilation of kFk_FkFâ€‹ then we have:

fn=1Nâˆ‘kfkeikn=R(xn)eikFxn+L(xn)eâˆ’ikFxnf_n =\frac{1}{\sqrt{N} }\sum_kf_ke^{ikn}= R(x_n)e^{ik_Fx_n}+L(x_n)e^{-ik_Fx_n} fnâ€‹=Nâ€‹1â€‹kâˆ‘â€‹fkâ€‹eikn=R(xnâ€‹)eikFâ€‹xnâ€‹+L(xnâ€‹)eâˆ’ikFâ€‹xnâ€‹

And because R(xn),L(xn)R(x_n),L(x_n)R(xnâ€‹),L(xnâ€‹) contain only the long wavelength components, then we consider it to be continuous. We write:

Ïˆ(x)=(R(x)L(x))\psi(x) = \begin{pmatrix} R(x)\\ L(x)\\ \end{pmatrix} Ïˆ(x)=(R(x)L(x)â€‹)

Then we have:

H1=âˆ’JâŠ¥âˆ«dxÏˆË‰iÎ³1âˆ‚xÏˆH_1 = -J_\perp \int dx \bar{\psi} i \gamma_1\partial_x\psi H1â€‹=âˆ’JâŠ¥â€‹âˆ«dxÏˆË‰â€‹iÎ³1â€‹âˆ‚xâ€‹Ïˆ

Notes on proof:

ÏˆË‰iÎ³1âˆ‚xÏˆ=i(Râ€ âˆ‚xRâˆ’Lâ€ âˆ‚xL)flâ€ fl+1+fl+1â€ fl=(Rlâ€ eâˆ’ikFl+Llâ€ eikFl)(Rl+1eikF(l+1)+Ll+1eâˆ’ikF(l+1))+h.c.=Rlâ€ eikFRl+1+Rlâ€ eâˆ’ikF(2l+1)Ll+1+Llâ€ eikF(2l+1)Rl+1+Llâ€ eâˆ’ikFLl+1+h.c.=iRlâ€ Rl+1âˆ’i(âˆ’1)lRlâ€ Ll+1+i(âˆ’1)lLlâ€ Rl+1âˆ’iLlâ€ Ll+1+h.c.â‰ˆiRlâ€ Rl+1âˆ’iLlâ€ Ll+1+h.c.\bar{\psi} i \gamma_1\partial_x\psi = i(R^\dagger\partial_xR-L^\dagger\partial_xL)\\ \begin{aligned} f_l^\dagger f_{l+1}+f_{l+1}^\dagger f_l &= (R^\dagger_le^{-ik_Fl}+L^\dagger_le^{ik_Fl})(R_{l+1}e^{ik_F(l+1)}+L_{l+1}e^{-ik_F(l+1)})+h.c.\\ & = R^\dagger_le^{ik_F}R_{l+1}+R^\dagger_le^{-ik_F(2l+1)}L_{l+1}+L^\dagger_le^{ik_F(2l+1)}R_{l+1}+L^\dagger_le^{-ik_F}L_{l+1}+h.c.\\ &= iR_l^\dagger R_{l+1}-i(-1)^lR_l^\dagger L_{l+1}+i(-1)^lL^\dagger_lR_{l+1}-iL^\dagger_l L_{l+1}+h.c.\\ &\approx iR_l^\dagger R_{l+1}-iL^\dagger_l L_{l+1}+h.c.\\ \end{aligned} ÏˆË‰â€‹iÎ³1â€‹âˆ‚xâ€‹Ïˆ=i(Râ€ âˆ‚xâ€‹Râˆ’Lâ€ âˆ‚xâ€‹L)flâ€ â€‹fl+1â€‹+fl+1â€ â€‹flâ€‹â€‹=(Rlâ€ â€‹eâˆ’ikFâ€‹l+Llâ€ â€‹eikFâ€‹l)(Rl+1â€‹eikFâ€‹(l+1)+Ll+1â€‹eâˆ’ikFâ€‹(l+1))+h.c.=Rlâ€ â€‹eikFâ€‹Rl+1â€‹+Rlâ€ â€‹eâˆ’ikFâ€‹(2l+1)Ll+1â€‹+Llâ€ â€‹eikFâ€‹(2l+1)Rl+1â€‹+Llâ€ â€‹eâˆ’ikFâ€‹Ll+1â€‹+h.c.=iRlâ€ â€‹Rl+1â€‹âˆ’i(âˆ’1)lRlâ€ â€‹Ll+1â€‹+i(âˆ’1)lLlâ€ â€‹Rl+1â€‹âˆ’iLlâ€ â€‹Ll+1â€‹+h.c.â‰ˆiRlâ€ â€‹Rl+1â€‹âˆ’iLlâ€ â€‹Ll+1â€‹+h.c.â€‹

Performing a Fourier transformation, we have:

R(x)=12Ï€âˆ«dkeikxR(k),âˆ‚xR=12Ï€âˆ«dkeikxikR(k)H1=âˆ‘kJâŠ¥k(Râ€ (k)R(k)âˆ’Lâ€ (k)L(k))R(x) = \frac{1}{2\pi}\int dk e^{ikx}R(k), \partial_xR = \frac{1}{2\pi}\int dk e^{ikx}ikR(k)\\ H_1 = \sum_k J_\perp k(R^\dagger(k)R(k)-L^\dagger(k)L(k)) R(x)=2Ï€1â€‹âˆ«dkeikxR(k),âˆ‚xâ€‹R=2Ï€1â€‹âˆ«dkeikxikR(k)H1â€‹=kâˆ‘â€‹JâŠ¥â€‹k(Râ€ (k)R(k)âˆ’Lâ€ (k)L(k))

To compute the JzJ_zJzâ€‹ term, we need to figure out:

fnâ€ fn=Rnâ€ Rn+Lnâ€ Ln+e2ikFn(Rnâ€ Ln+Lnâ€ Rn)f^\dagger_nf_n = R_n^\dagger R_n+L^\dagger_nL_n+e^{2ik_Fn}(R_n^\dagger L_n+L^\dagger_nR_n) fnâ€ â€‹fnâ€‹=Rnâ€ â€‹Rnâ€‹+Lnâ€ â€‹Lnâ€‹+e2ikFâ€‹n(Rnâ€ â€‹Lnâ€‹+Lnâ€ â€‹Rnâ€‹)

entry.title: Notes on the CFT yellow book(1)
entry.content: This is a note for the book-reading seminar of the CFT yellow book, chapter 2.

entry.title: TRG Code
entry.content: This is the code for calculating the partition function of 2D Ising model, using TRG(Tensor Renormalization Group) algorithm. The notes of this method might be updated in the future.
